1962-1972.title: ESTABLISHMENT OF AIR STAFF OFFICE AND SERVICE INDEPENDENCE
1962-1972.summary: The NAF established the Office of Chief of Air Staff and gained full service independence with its own rank structure.
1962-1972.content: On 17 December 1969, Brigadier Emmanuel E Ikwue was appointed the Fifth Commander of the Nigerian Air Force and later became the First Nigerian Air Force Commander to hold the office now designated as the Office of the Chief of the Air Staff. On 29 July 1975, Air Vice Marshall John Nmadu Yisa-Doko was appointed the Sixth Chief of the Air Staff, becoming the First Airman to be appointed Chief of the Air Staff and the First to attain the rank of Air Vice Marshall in the Nigerian Air Force. In 1976, the Nigerian Air Force was presented with its Colours by General Olusegun Obasanjo at the First Air Force Day. On 1 April 1976, the Federal Military Government authorized the adoption of a complete Air Force rank structure to give the Nigerian Air Force full-service independence.

1962-1972.title: ORGANIZATIONAL DEVELOPMENT AND EXPANSION
1962-1972.summary: The NAF established specialized commands, introduced new insignia, and promoted its first Air Marshal.
1962-1972.content: On 15 April 1980, Air Vice Marshal Abdullahi Dominic Bello was appointed the Seventh Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 31 December 1983. In 1982, the Nigerian Air Force Logistics Command was established in Lagos. New wings for the Nigerian Air Force aircrew were introduced in 1983 to replace the foreign ones in use. On 01 January 1984, Air Marshal Ibrahim Mahmud Alfa was appointed the Eighth Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 01 January 1990. On 1 October 1987, Ibrahim Mahmud Alfa became the First Nigerian Air Force officer to be promoted to the rank of Air Marshal. In June 1988, the Nigerian Air Force was organized into 4 specialized Commands: Tactical Command (Makurdi), Training Command (Kaduna), Logistics Command (Lagos), and Airlift Command (Ibadan). In 1989, the Nigerian Air Force unveiled its first locally built trainer aircraft dubbed the 'Air Beetle'.

1962-1972.title: MODERNIZATION AND TRAGIC ACCIDENTS
1962-1972.summary: The NAF continued leadership transitions while experiencing significant accidents and achieving historic firsts.
1962-1972.content: Air Marshal Nuraini Oladimeji Yussuff was appointed the Ninth Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 30 January 1992. On 31 January 1992, Air Marshal Akin Dada was appointed the Tenth Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 16 September 1993. On 26 September 1992, a fatal air crash involving a Nigerian Air Force Lockheed C-130H Hercules 911 occurred 3 minutes after take-off from Lagos when 3 engines failed, killing all 158 passengers and crew members at Ejigbo Canal. On 17 September 1993, Air Vice Marshal Femi John Femi was appointed the Eleventh Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 29 March 1996. On 30 March 1996, Air Marshal Nsikak-Abasi Essien Eduok was appointed as the Twelfth Chief of the Air Staff. On 9 June 1998, Air Marshal Al-Amin Daggash became the First Nigerian Air Force Chief of Defence Staff. On 10 March 1999, Habibah Ruth Garba became the First female Air Commodore in the Nigerian Air Force. On 29 May 1999, Air Marshal Isaac Mohammed Alfa was appointed as the Thirteenth Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 23 April 2001.
1962-1972.keyPersonnel: Air Marshal Al-Amin Daggash (First NAF CDS), Air Commodore Habibah Ruth Garba (First Female Air Commodore)

1962-1972.title: NEW MILLENNIUM DEVELOPMENTS
1962-1972.summary: The NAF achieved significant technological milestones and established new training institutions.
1962-1972.content: On 24 April 2001, Air Marshal Jonah Domfa Wuyep was appointed as the Fourteenth Chief of the Air Staff, serving until 31 May 2006. On 01 June 2006, Air Marshal Paul Dike was appointed as the Fifteenth Chief of the Air Staff. On 17 September 2006, an air crash involving several Army officers occurred in Obudu, Cross-River State. On 12 March 2008, the 320 Technical Training Group was renamed Air Force Institute of Technology (AFIT) following expansion and full accreditation by NBTE and NUC as well as its affiliation to Cranfield University. On 20 August 2008, Air Marshal Paul Dike became the First Nigerian Air Force officer to attain the rank of Air Chief Marshal upon his appointment as Chief of Defence Staff. On the same day, Air Marshal Oluseyi Petinrin was appointed as the Sixteenth Chief of the Air Staff. In 2010, the Nigerian Air Force designed and built its First indigenous Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) dubbed 'GULMA' and was unveiled by former President Goodluck Jonathan in Kaduna. On 19 September 2010, Air Marshal MD Umar was appointed as the Seventeenth Chief of the Air Staff.

1962-1972.title: EXPANSION AND GENDER MILESTONES
1962-1972.summary: The NAF established new commands, commissioned first female pilots, and achieved significant operational milestones.
1962-1972.content: On 29 March 2011, the Nigerian Air Force established the Mobility Command with its Headquarters in Yenogoa. On 9 December 2011, the Nigerian Air Force commissioned its First female pilot, Flt Lt Blessing Liman. On 04 October 2012, Air Marshal Alex Sabundu Badeh was appointed the Eighteenth Chief of the Air Staff. On 16 January 2014, Air Marshal Adesola Nunayon Amosu was appointed the Nineteenth Chief of the Air Staff. On 18 April 2014, the Nigerian Air Force marked its 50 years Golden Jubilee Celebration. On 25 September 2014, the CH-3A UCAV was inducted into the Nigerian Air Force fleet. On 13 July 2015, Air Marshal Sadique Baba Abubakar was appointed the Twentieth Chief of the Air Staff. On 19 November 2016, the Nigerian Air Force established the Special Operations Command (SOC) in Bauchi. On 8 June 2017, the Nigerian Air Force established the Nigerian Air Force Tailoring Workshop in Kaduna. On 15 February 2018, the Nigerian Air Force inducted its first locally-built operational UAV drone dubbed the 'TSAIGUMI'. On 16 April 2018, the winging of the First Set of Liberian pilots trained for the Liberian Armed Forces took place. On 2 May 2018, the Nigerian Air Force established the Ground Training Command (GTC) in Enugu. On 15 October 2019, the Nigerian Air Force winged Lieutenant Kafayat Sanni as its First female combat fighter jet pilot and Lieutenant Tolulope Arotile as its first female combat helicopter pilot. Master Warrant Officer Grace Garba became the First female Senior Non-Commissioned Officer (SNCO) to be promoted to Air Warrant Officer. On 28 May 2020, the Nigerian Air Force recorded its First all-female crew to conduct an operational Intelligence, Surveillance and Reconnaissance (ISR) mission, and Flying Officer Oluwabunmi Ijelu became the First female officer to become a Captain on a NAF aircraft.

1962-1972.title: CURRENT ERA AND RECENT DEVELOPMENTS
1962-1972.summary: The NAF continues to evolve under current leadership while facing operational challenges and achieving new milestones.
1962-1972.content: On 26 January 2021, Air Marshal Oladayo Isiaka Amao was appointed the Twenty-first Chief of the Air Staff, an office he holds till date. On 22 May 2021, a fatal plane crash occurred killing the Chief of Army Staff, Lt Gen Ibrahim Attahiru and 10 other Nigerian Army officers including crew members. On 18 July 2021, Alpha Jet pilot Flight Lieutenant Abayomi Dairo was shot down by armed bandits in Zamfara State. He successfully ejected from the plane, evaded capture and made his way to the base in the area, where he was received by the Chief of Defence Staff and the Chief of Air Staff, demonstrating the courage and resilience of NAF personnel in the face of adversity.
